docs.text: We’re building a trusted, searchable repository (and later on, a community hub) so Black families in Metro Detroit don’t have to dig for culturally competent care. Your feedback makes these guides better for the next caregiver, thank you for being here.

docs.title: How to Choose a Doula in Metro Detroit
docs.text:
Finding the right doula shouldn’t feel like a scavenger hunt. This guide gives you a simple, culturally-rooted process to locate and vet Black doulas across Metro Detroit.

Shortcut: Browse the community-vetted directory: Find Black Doulas →

docs.title: What a Doula Does (and Doesn’t)
docs.text:
• Birth doula: Prepares you for labor, supports you during birth, advocates for your preferences.
  • Postpartum doula: Supports recovery, newborn care, feeding, sleep, and household transitions.
  • They don’t replace medical care. Doulas provide emotional, informational, and physical support—not clinical care.

docs.title: Step-by-Step: Find + Vet Your Doula
docs.text:
1. Search locally Use filters for city/ZIP, virtual vs. in-person, languages, and insurance/Medicaid/self-pay.
  2. Check experience fit Settings (hospital, center, home), specialties (VBAC, multiples, high-risk, trauma-informed).
  3. Cultural concordance matters Prioritize doulas embedded in Detroit’s Black birthwork community.
  4. Interview 2–3 doulas (30–45 min each) Compare notes right after.

docs.title: Interview Questions (Copy/Paste)
docs.text:
• Availability & backup coverage for your due window
  • Support approach in hospital settings; advocacy style
  • Local relationships with L&D units and midwifery practices
  • Inclusion practices; experience with diverse family structures
  • Lactation support scope & referrals
  • What’s included vs. add-ons; emergency scenarios; fees/sliding scale

docs.title: Budgeting & Payment
docs.text:
• Typical packages: prenatals + birth + 1–2 postpartum visits.
  • Ask about sliding scale, payment plans, and any community funds.
  • Insurance/Medicaid pilots exist—confirm in writing.

Tip: Popular doulas book 2–4 months ahead.

docs.title: Red Flags
docs.text:
• Outcome guarantees
  • Dismissive of your preferences/culture
  • No written agreement or unclear backup

docs.title: Preparing to Work Together
docs.text:
• Birth preferences worksheet
  • Support team roles (partner, doula, family)
  • Hospital policies (visitors, induction/C-section protocols)

docs.title: Funding & Benefits for Black Families (Michigan)
docs.text:
This page is a starting map to programs Michigan families often use during pregnancy, postpartum, and early childhood. Always confirm details on official sites.

Navigation tip: Start applications on the official Michigan benefits portal. Keep IDs, pay stubs, lease, and birth records ready.

docs.title: Core Programs to Explore
docs.text:
• Health coverage (pregnancy & baby) – Medicaid options for pregnant people and infants/children
  • Food & nutrition – WIC and related nutrition support
  • Cash/basic needs – cash assistance, utility help, housing support (income/situation dependent)
  • Child care assistance – subsidies to reduce daycare/in-home care costs
  • Early learning – Head Start/Early Head Start and state preschool
  • Home visiting – pregnancy–age 3 family support programs

Log application dates, case numbers, and contacts.

docs.title: Tips for a Smoother Application
docs.text: Create a document kit, report changes fast, appeal if denied, and request interpreters/accommodations if needed.

docs.title: Community & Bridge Supports
docs.text: Ask doulas about community funds/sliding scale; look for diaper banks, housing/utility aid, and ride programs for appointments.

docs.title: Postpartum & Lactation Support (Metro Detroit)
docs.text:
Use this guide to find local lactation help, postpartum doulas, and community resources rooted in the needs of Black families.

Need a provider now? - Postpartum Doulas - Lactation Consultants / IBCLC

docs.title: The Postpartum Plan (Quick Template)
docs.text:
• Primary support: partner/family + doula (roles + schedules)
  • Feeding plan: chest/breast, bottle, combo; who to call for latch issues
  • Meals/chores: meal train, groceries, laundry plan
  • Sleep: shifts, safe sleep setup
  • Appointments: pediatric, OB/midwife, lactation follow-ups
  • Mind: mood check-ins, anxiety, birth processing

Print this section and keep a copy on the fridge.

docs.title: Lactation: When to Get Help
docs.text:
• Painful latch beyond the first minute
  • Cracked/bleeding nipples or mastitis symptoms
  • Low output/weight concerns or <6 wet diapers/day after day 5
  • Pumping/return-to-work planning

Who to call: IBCLC (clinical), CLC/CLE (education), peer counselors (community).

docs.title: Mental Health & Emotional Recovery
docs.text: It’s normal to feel overwhelmed. Seek help for persistent sadness, anxiety, panic, or intrusive thoughts. Ask about perinatal mental health clinicians and group support.

docs.title: Practical Setups That Help
docs.text: • Nourish corner, diaper stations, night shift bin, visitor policy (“helpers do chores first”).

docs.title: Body Care & Healing
docs.text: Body care after pregnancy is about healing — not “bouncing back.”

docs.title: Common Postpartum Body Concerns
docs.text:
• Pain or soreness
  • Scar healing (C-section or tearing)
  • Hormonal skin changes
  • Hair loss
  • Joint or back pain
  • Fatigue and weakness

docs.title: Types of Body Care That May Help
docs.text:
Depending on your needs, body care may include:

  • Pelvic floor therapy
  • Physical therapy
  • Postpartum massage
  • Chiropractic care (with postpartum experience)
  • Scar mobilization
  • Gentle movement or rehab-based exercise

docs.title: How to Choose a Provider
docs.text:
When looking for body care support:

  • Ask if they specialize in postpartum clients
  • Ask about experience with C-sections or birth recovery
  • Ask about comfort working with Black patients
  • Ask what training they have related to postpartum care

docs.title: Practical Reminder
docs.text:
Start with:

  • One concern
  • One provider
  • One appointment

docs.title: Lactation Support
docs.text: Lactation support is help with feeding — breast, bottle, pumping, or combination feeding.

docs.title: What Lactation Support Helps With
docs.text:
Lactation consultants can help with:

  • Latching issues
  • Painful feeding
  • Low or oversupply
  • Pumping setup and schedules
  • Bottle feeding concerns
  • Feeding multiples
  • Transitioning feeding methods

docs.title: When to Get Lactation Support
docs.text:
Consider lactation support if:

  • Feeding hurts
  • Your baby isn’t gaining weight as expected
  • You feel stressed or unsure about feeding
  • You want to pump but don’t know where to start

docs.title: How to Find Lactation Support
docs.text:
Start here:

  • International Lactation Consultant Association (IBCLC Finder)
  • Black Breastfeeding Week

Search tips:

  • Look for IBCLC credentials
  • Ask if they offer virtual visits
  • Ask if they have experience supporting Black families

docs.title: Insurance & Cost
docs.text:
• Some insurance plans cover lactation support
  • Many hospitals offer initial visits
  • Community organizations may offer free or low-cost help

docs.title: Pelvic Floor Therapy
docs.text:
Pelvic floor therapy helps with recovery after pregnancy and birth. It is not only for people who had complications.

Many postpartum symptoms are common — but not something you have to live with.

docs.title: What Pelvic Floor Therapy Helps With
docs.text:
Pelvic floor therapy can help with:

  • Pain during or after sex
  • Leaking urine or stool
  • Pelvic pain or pressure
  • Core weakness or separation (diastasis recti)
  • Pain after vaginal birth or C-section
  • Feeling “not connected” to your core

docs.title: When to Consider Pelvic Floor Therapy
docs.text:
Consider pelvic floor therapy if:

  • You’re postpartum and still uncomfortable
  • You were never assessed after birth
  • You were told symptoms were “normal” but they persist
  • You want support returning to movement or exercise

docs.title: How to Find a Pelvic Floor Therapist
docs.text:
Start here:

  • APTA Pelvic Health Physical Therapist Directory

Search tips:

  • Look for “pelvic health” or “women’s health”
  • Ask if they treat postpartum and post-C-section patients
  • Ask if they have experience with postpartum care

docs.title: Black Pelvic Floor Therapists (Metro Detroit)
docs.text:
If you are looking for a Black pelvic floor therapist in Metro Detroit:

Pelvic Noire Founded by Dr. Kamaria Washington, Pelvic Noire centers pelvic health care for Black women and birthing people, with a strong focus on postpartum recovery and education. https://www.pelvicnoire.com/

docs.title: Insurance & Referrals
docs.text:
• Some providers require a referral; some do not
  • Call your insurance and ask about “pelvic floor physical therapy”
  • Ask your OB or midwife directly for a referral if needed

docs.title: Therapy & Mental Health
docs.text: Pregnancy and postpartum can affect mental health in serious ways.

docs.title: Common Reasons Parents Seek Therapy
docs.text:
• Anxiety
  • Depression
  • Postpartum mood disorders
  • Rage or irritability
  • Grief or loss
  • Birth trauma
  • Feeling disconnected or overwhelmed

docs.title: When to Seek Support
docs.text:
Consider therapy if:

  • You feel persistently overwhelmed
  • You feel numb or detached
  • You’re anxious most of the day
  • You’re not sleeping even when you can

If you are thinking about harming yourself or others, seek immediate help.

docs.title: Where to Find Postpartum Mental Health Support
docs.text:
Start here:

  • Postpartum Support International (PSI)
  • Therapy for Black Girls

PSI offers:

  • Provider directories
  • Support groups
  • Helplines
  • Resources for Black parents

docs.title: Insurance & Access
docs.text:
• Many therapists offer virtual sessions
  • Some accept insurance; some offer sliding scale
  • Ask specifically about postpartum experience

docs.title: Pregnancy
docs.text:
Pregnancy can be exciting, confusing, and overwhelming — sometimes all at once.

This section focuses on what to expect, how to prepare, and how to advocate for yourself, especially as a Black parent navigating medical systems.

docs.title: Start Here
docs.text:
If you’re

  • black & pregnant
  • black & postpartum
  • black & parenting
  • parenting a black child

and feeling overwhelmed — you’re in the right place.

This section will help you understand how to use this guide and set expectations for what’s ahead.

docs.title: You can use this guide to:
docs.text:
• Learn about resources and services you didn’t know existed
  • Find support spaces that feel culturally safe
  • Put words to feelings you haven’t been able to name yet
  • Figure out what kind of help might actually help you

Some sections may resonate deeply. Others may not apply to you right now — and that’s okay.

docs.title: How the Guide Is Organized
docs.text:
The guide is organized by life phase and type of support, not by trends or timelines.

You’ll find sections for:

  • Pregnancy
  • Birth and postpartum realities
  • Support and community
  • Care and healing
  • Resources and services
  • Parenting beyond the newborn stage

Each section is meant to stand on its own. You can jump around freely.

docs.title: Why This Guide Has a Black Lens
docs.text:
Black parents face unique realities, medically, culturally, and socially.

We are more likely to:

  • Have our pain minimized
  • Receive less information about available care
  • Be expected to “push through” instead of being supported
  • Be praised for strength instead of offered rest

This guide centers Black experiences without centering fear.

It highlights care paths, language, and resources that many of us only discover after struggling, often because someone else finally told us they existed.

We believe information should not be gatekept.

docs.title: What This Guide Is, and Is Not
docs.text:
This guide is:

  • Honest
  • Calm
  • Practical
  • Grounded in lived experience
  • Meant to be revisited as your needs change

This guide is not:

  • Medical advice
  • A replacement for professional care
  • A checklist you must complete
  • A judgment of how you parent

docs.title: A Gentle Reality Check
docs.text:
Parenthood, especially motherhood, is beautiful. Parenthood, especially motherhood, is also hard.

Both can be true — especially for Black parents.

This guide exists because many of us enter pregnancy and parenthood with love, faith, and excitement, but without clear information about what life can actually feel like on the other side.

This is not meant to scare you. It’s meant to ground you.

docs.title: Community Spaces
docs.text:
Community spaces offer support that appointments often don’t.

These are places designed for connection, not rushing or fixing.

docs.title: What Community Spaces Provide
docs.text:
Many community spaces offer: - Emotional support - Shared experience - Education - Gentle accountability - Relief from isolation

They are especially important during pregnancy and postpartum, when support often drops off.

docs.title: Fourth Tri Sanctuary
docs.text:
Focus: Postpartum support

Fourth Tri centers the often-overlooked postpartum period and provides: - Postpartum education - Support spaces - Community connection

This is a key resource for the “after birth” phase.

Website: Fourth Tri Sanctuary

docs.title: Honey for Moms
docs.text:
Focus: Black maternal wellness

Honey for Moms creates intentional space for Black mothers to: - Connect - Rest - Speak honestly - Feel less alone

This is community-centered care.

Website: Honey. For Moms

docs.title: Nature’s Playhouse
docs.text:
Focus: Families, children, and connection

Nature’s Playhouse offers: - Family-centered spaces - Play-based connection - Community building alongside children

Support does not have to happen without your kids.

Website: Natures PlayHouse

docs.title: How to Use This List
docs.text:
You don’t need to try everything.

Pick: - One space - One session - One event

If it fits, great. If it doesn’t, on to the next!

docs.title: How to Show Up and Ask for Help
docs.text:
If you are overwhelmed, exhausted, or stretched thin, you do not need a mindset shift. You need support you can actually access.

This page is about how to ask — not why you should.

docs.title: Step 1: Identify What Kind of Help You Need
docs.text:
You don’t need perfect clarity. Pick the closest match.

Emotional support

  • Someone to listen
  • A support group
  • A therapist
  • A postpartum support space

Physical support

  • Help with the baby
  • Help overnight
  • Help with meals
  • Help with household tasks

Information support

  • Understanding postpartum symptoms
  • Learning about available services
  • Help navigating benefits or care options

If everything feels overwhelming, start with emotional support.

docs.title: Step 2: Use Short, Direct Language
docs.text:
You do not need to explain your whole situation.

Use one sentence.

docs.title: Examples you can copy:
docs.text:
• “I’m overwhelmed and need support.”
  • “I’m not okay and need help finding resources.”
  • “Do you know any postpartum support groups?”
  • “I need help during the day / overnight.”
  • “Can you help me figure out next steps?”

That is enough information to start.

docs.title: Step 3: Decide Where to Ask
docs.text:
Choose one place. Not all of them.

For emotional support

  • Postpartum support groups
  • Community spaces
  • A therapist
  • A trusted friend

For physical help

  • Partner
  • Family member
  • Postpartum doula
  • Night support / newborn doula

For guidance

  • Community organizations
  • Lactation consultants
  • Postpartum care providers
  • WIC or local maternal health orgs

If one option doesn’t work, move to the next.

docs.title: Step 4: Lower the Bar for Showing Up
docs.text:
You do NOT need to:

  • Be prepared
  • Share your story
  • Speak the whole time
  • Stay the full session

You CAN:

  • Join late
  • Leave early
  • Listen only
  • Say “I’m just here today”

Showing up once counts.

docs.title: Step 5: If You’re Asking Someone You Know
docs.text:
Be specific. Vague requests often don’t get met.

Instead of:

  • “I need help”

Try:

  • “Can you watch the baby for one hour?”
  • “Can you bring a meal this week?”
  • “Can you sit with me while I rest?”
  • “Can you help me find postpartum resources?”

Specific asks are easier to respond to.

docs.title: Step 6: If Help Feels Hard to Ask For
docs.text:
This usually means:

  • You’ve been the strong one
  • You’re used to managing alone
  • You don’t want to be a burden

None of that means you don’t need help. It means you’ve been carrying too much.

docs.title: Step 7: Set Boundaries Early
docs.text:
Getting help does NOT mean:

  • Taking advice you didn’t ask for
  • Staying in spaces that feel unsafe
  • Explaining your choices repeatedly

You are allowed to say:

  • “That’s not helpful for me.”
  • “I’m not looking for advice right now.”
  • “This space isn’t a good fit.”

You can leave and try something else.

docs.title: If You Don’t Know Where to Start
docs.text:
Start here:

  • One support group
  • One community space
  • One conversation

Support is not something you earn. It is something you access.

That is the goal.
